Day 24 Split plot designs July 15th, 2025 24.1 Announcements HW 4 due Friday 24.2 Split plot designs Split-plot designs are multi-level designed experiments. Randomization happens in different domains. For example: Figure 24.1: Step 1 designing a split plot design in a CRD Figure 24.2: Step 1 designing a split plot design in a blocked structure Figure 24.3: Step 2 designing a split plot design Remember: Blocks are groups of approximately similar experimental units. Data generated by blocked designs may be analyzed as \(y_{ij} = \mu +\tau_i + b_j + \varepsilon_{ij}\), where \(y_{ij}\) is the observed response for the \(i\)th treatment in the \(j\)th block, \(\tau_i\) is the effect of the \(i\)th treatment, \(b_j\) is the effect of the \(j\)th block, \(\varepsilon_{ij}\) is the residual of the \(i\)th treatment in the \(j\)th block. 24.2.1 Applied case: split-plot design Grain yield was measured at for a split-plot experiment of barley with fungicide treatments. Within each block, fungicides were randomized and then, barley varieties were randomly applied to smaller plots. library(tidyverse) library(agridat) library(lme4) library(DHARMa) df_splitplot <- agridat::durban.splitplot m_splitplot <- lmer(yield ~ fung * gen + (1|block/fung), data = df_splitplot) VarCorr(m_splitplot) ## Groups Name Std.Dev. ## fung:block (Intercept) 0.11737 ## block (Intercept) 0.16972 ## Residual 0.28119
